comments.commentBody: I am sorry for this but I don't see any way around it. We are becoming as people less able to communicate and interact well, in general, without Asperger's intervening. Thus the fall off in jobs for those with poor social skills or those who won't go along with the politics of jobs requiring they do. I always used to say, it won't be the job that changes, it will have to be me.

If businesses are savvy about hiring, they shouldn't be avoiding individuals on the autistic spectrum, who are often quite ethical and hardworking, and, while often socially awkward, are rarely socially nasty. Businesses should instead be avoiding the charming sociopaths who look great in interviews but make life miserable for everyone but their superiors as they work their way through the ranks.
When people talk about poor social skills, they often conflate two very different things.

The increased emphasis on social skills in the workplace is disastrous for people with Asperger's. Aspies are physiologically incapable of picking up on non-verbal communication and therefore can't develop the social skills that neurotypical people do. I'm not referring to basic social skills such as being polite and cooperative; an Aspie can learn those.

In my experience as a software technical writer, the skills to understand social subtleties were essential. As an Aspie, I couldn't understand the social dynamics of the workplace. I therefore suffered harsh consequences, even though my technical and writing/information design skills were superb.

90% of people with Asperger's are unemployed or underemployed, even when they are talented. This emphasis on social skills is why.
Used winter squash instead of summer. Used left over grilled pork tenderloin and skipped the browning step.  Added chopped greens at the end. Super yummy. Whole family enjoyed it.

Response to Mr Robin P Little in Conway SC: """Most schizophrenics are never going to meet and have active, fruitful relationships with these psychoanalysts. (...) and they certainly aren't going to be bright, educated, bi-lingual people who studied languages in college."""

Hey-- Hey, hey, hey. I'm schizophrenic, yet I'm fully bilingual, and have a university degree in math. I'd had an active, fruitful relationship with a psychiatrist for 26 years, then he died. Granted, we were doing talking therapy but not psychoanalysis.

Please don't misunderstand me. I am not dissing your sis. It's just that we, as a group, are affected in a very diverse way by our illness, both in depth and breadth -- diverse both in intensity and duration of symptoms, and in duration and intensity of take-away effects. Response to medication is also individualistic.

I have a fundamentally different take on these questions of automation, the obsolescing of human labor and the qualities and characteristics that as a consequence we might expect to prevail in some future where all or most work is performed by software and hardware.

All these analyses assume a limit to automation as their point of departure -- that automation is incapable of immense and subtle flexibility, cooperation – even empathy. To me, these are merely more sophisticated response criteria that we haven’t yet advanced far enough to make real. But we advance by plateaus of sophistication, stabilizing one then building on it to the next plateau, always significantly more sophisticated than the last – then that becomes the plateau on which we build the next level, and so on. I see a lot of sophistication today, and the intervals between the plateaus to be narrowing. We have the potential to become VERY sophisticated fairly fast.

So, rejecting Ms. Miller’s premises as they relate to the lead we persist in burying, what we learn in preschool may or may not be crucial at work in that fully realized future (that may not be that far off); but it would be important during interim steps until software became very sophisticated. My problem with the whole question is that we need to figure out how human beings are going to survive in a world utterly alien to today’s, where we trade labor for the ability to consume; and I distrust distractions from pursuing that understanding.

The reason this treatment worked so well is that the analyst was able to accept - and even invite - the patient's negative impressions about him. This neutralizes the toxic feelings that make the patient so ill.

It's hard work. Kudos to Christopher Billas for withstanding her turning him into a dragon, and for the eloquent writing.

Oh, and also, curing patients through the transference projections works with everybody - rich or poor. See Neil Altman's work and my own stories about treatment for more on that...

What a toxic environment. Your child faces malevolent peers at every turn, whose mission in life is to turn every act against them.

What parent would willingly send their charge into what they fully realize is a snakepit? Everyone keeps telling me that school leaves kids well-socialized. Socialized to do what? After a decade of school they seem to turn out more sociopath than socialized. Who teaches them to treat one another like this? How can such viciousness be accepted as normal?

And once you do figure out all the ways your daughter will be harassed and degraded no matter which way she turns, the solution is not to burn the whole institution to the ground and start over? The solution is to try to thread the needle between the contradictory demands of her judgmental peers and be happy to somehow survive it with a shred of self-respect?

Horrors.

This was a perfectly delicious dish!  I sauteed the mushrooms first cuz I like them a little golden; also I  had to use white and shitakes.  Also, I doubled the coconut milk cuz I like lots of sauce. The lime juice and zest - essential!, it added such a clear note of flavor.  It was the best use I have ever made of cilantro, which I love.  The dish looked beautiful, colorful and bright, and the flavors - all could be tasted, nothing was muddied, all in harmony.
It was okay,  but a lot of work for a dish not that distinctive from other chicken thigh recipes.

We made this to go with the Coconut Red Curry with Tofu.  The naan was really good, and I think will be better as my GF and I become more skilled.  I think the flour needed a little more liquid, and I think it could have been 24 pieces for smaller, thinner bread, and I think we should have rolled it thinner, and the pan should have been hotter.  Very tasty, despite our shortcomings, and we will definitely make this again!

The self-righteous, judgmental and seemingly non-empathic nature of this reply took my breath away. As a psychotherapist myself, I was moved by the lengths to which Dr. Kuchuk went to make himself available to his clients even in the face of his own dislocation. How anyone can see in these laudable efforts something that "reeks of financial desperation or greed" is completely beyond me. I am also perplexed how anyone could read these few lines and conclude Charles has Narcissistic Personality Disorder. This reply is a frightening example of the dangers of reducing psychotherapy to an exercise in diagnosis. For myself, I found this article a wonderful example of the power of meeting clients with ultimate genuineness and learning that what heals in psychotherapy is not any particular technique, but the honest, human relationship. As I always try to keep in mind, and as I teach my students, we must always remember Yalom's wisdom: "We are, all of us, in this together."

I was not prescribed omeprazole for reflux, but to prevent damage to my GI tract following throat cancer.  But I quit it after having some heart irregularity that seemed to be caused by low magnesium levels.  Now I use ranitidine (generic Zantac);  it's very cheap and works well.  Have you tried it?
Floculent --- excellent word that I had never heard before!

This was delicious, however, there was some foaming and then a percipitate/floculent material in the sauce that appeared when I reheated it after the overnight marinade. Any ideas what this might be? I tried skimming and then straining it and that helped a bit, but I'm wondering if others saw the same thing and whether it's anything that needs to be removed.
Not always a good idea to eat the Tums if you are taking other drugs at that time.  At least check with your pharmacist to see if there is a negative interaction.
Wessexmom--Probably why he takes it in the afternoon, not the evening.

Reply to James B: We must be careful not to confuse a need of replenishing personal energies by social surroundings with immaturity.

I am an introvert like you, James, I also max out at 20-25 hours in a week on social interaction. Let's not forget, however, that others may be different; extroversion is not a sign of immaturity, but a way of existing (due to mutational differences in the past history of our species, I reckon.)

The ability to sit down and do your work should be the goal of all mature, adult workers. Just because you are an extrovert doesn't mean that the world should bend to your needs for interaction. And it should be made clear to you. If you can't do your job because you need a lot of hand holding, perhaps this isn't the job for you.

My 'social capacity' tops out at about 25 hours per week, yet often by Thursday these hours are used up in meetings or by the 'socially skilled' who just can't perform without constant attention.

We must be careful not to confuse immaturity with skillful communication.

So instead of talking about it, you are publishing it in the NYT?

I can't get over the "publcness" of so many families these days. How on earth does each parent who blogs or reports regularly on social media about his or her family expect the children who are the subjects to benignly accept their lives being pasted all over the Web?

This dinner was delicious and easy - To save some time I used Trader Joe's mirepoix, herbs from my garden and bulk sweet Italian sausage from our local deli. Everything else was already in the pantry. Both my husband and son asked for seconds and my son burst out, "Oh my God, this is amazing, what did you do to it!"

Regarding its street performance, he took a road test.   Regarding the fuel economy, the car has a street reputation of beating its EPA economy numbers, a fact known by most diesel enthusiasts who bought this car.
this is soooo good... used mustard grains instead of dry powdered mustard... and it is so good... the crust of cheese and pasta is just excellent... this one will stay for many years to come

A dash or three of Worcestershire sauce at the middle or later stages of cooking is a touch my guests and myself have always enjoyed when making biscuits and gravy. I will make this recipe without any additions first, then try it with the sauce and some diced softened onions to see what I get.

Little kids don't always want to be something (someone) scary. My son wanted to be Peter Pan and Robin Hood and then Superman and Batman, all his heroes. And his sister wanted to be a parrot, after she went through the sidekick phase (Tinkerbell, Supergirl). We made costumes out of whatever we had, or bought pajamas.

I liked and often used the rule that costumes were not to be bought outright (although I admit I did buy a wonderful parrot that got passed down to my niece and nephew) but instead cobbled together with things from home and whatever we could find at the thrift store or make ourselves.

I feel fortunate that my kids are Millennials who left Halloween behind in high school and liked inventing their own costumes.
THIS is what journalism looks like.
Not in my town - just little kids and middle school students.  And no one is "sexy" that much at that age.
Often they go to parties, instead. In - yes - sexy costumes.
I kept waiting for signs that this post was tongue in cheek, but they never came.  I am left wondering where these kids are wearing the costumes.  Do teenagers actually go trick-or-treating?

'Rut we would have to get there in a very different way than the Danes.'

What's about getting there like the rest of Europe? -(perhaps with the exception of Greece)

The exchange on Denmark is quite straightforward. Denmark is different. It is a rather monoethnic state with a population of five million. Some kind of consensus is easily achieved. There are minorities -- a small Tamil group and people from Greenland but they are tiny groups in relation to the whole. Even at that there are lots of true conservatives, racially intolerant groups, and even fundamentalist Christans. Nonetheless, Denmark just doesn't scale up to the US. That doesn't mean that a single payer healthcare system and free post-secondary education wouldn't go a long way toward solving lots of problems in the US. Rut we would have to get there in a very different way than the Danes.

What are tbe odds of this Congress revising laws and appropriating funds to avoid a shutdown of rail service in the Democratic Northeast? I wouldn't take that bet, even at 10 to 1.

But you can bet there is some serious horsetrading going behind the scenes.

"OK, we cut out Medicaid payments to Planned Parenthood and roll back new EPA rules on coal power plants and waterways and millions of your liberals get to work on time, at least for 3 more months.

But if you want the debt ceiling too, that's gonna cost you a little more. We're thinking off-shore oil permits, our favorite little pipeline from the tar pits and restoring the Bush tax cuts.

And forget about the Highway Trust Fund. You can't afford it, unless you want to help us get rid of Obamacare, root and branch.

But I did hear that the bitumin from those tar sands is great for filling potholes. Just avoid the bridges."
